review_title: I was so glad to have a good experience working at my alma mater as a mentor.
job_title: Mentor in West Windsor, NJ
pros: I love the beautiful West Windsor campus in NJ. I was liked by my supervisors. I enjoyed working with the students in the D.R.E.A.M. program as a mentor. I formed mentor-mentee relationships with the students in the program. I was able to connect with the students with intellectual disabilities as their mentor.
cons: There were no cons. I really enjoyed working at my alma mater getting $9 an hour as a mentor. There were no cons.

review_title: Good hours & benefits, but not keeping up with the modern world, especially in terms of remote work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Windsor, NJ
pros: -Reliable 35-hour workweek for full-time employees (usually 9 - 5 with 1 hour lunch break), with reduced hours in the summer -Good health, dental, vision, & retirement benefits, plus tuition remission for employee & dependents, though salary is a bit low -Institution is demonstrably committed to diversity and inclusion, and strongly supports its mission to ensure success for all students
cons: -Institution is averse to change -Process documentation is fragmentary and mostly consists of senior employees saying "this is the way we've always done it" -Institution is not supportive of remote work post-covid

job_title: Payroll Accountant in West Windsor, NJ
pros: it was n easy going environment

review_title: Come for the prospect of full time, stay for the continuing lie.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in West Windsor, NJ
pros:
Decent working environment overall. 
Good departmental coordinators.
One of the highest adjunct salaries in the state.
Relative freedom, depending on the department.
cons:
DYSFUNCTIONAL MANAGEMENT -The MCCC Board of Trustees is dysfunctional.  A vote of "no confidence" in the Board by full-time faculty has been rumored for some time. These votes have no teeth, however. Business as usual will probably result. Just like the vote of "no confidence" in the now disgraced College President.

The College President was just escorted off campus by security for wrongdoings after a months-long investigation. A new President begins in two months.

Each of the VPs need administrative assistants at $40k-$60k. Some VPs even have two assistants to keep up on their tik tock and facebook game. All of the VPs get to work from home and have the administrative assistants do most of the work, as with the Divisional Deans. 

Many of the Divisional Deans are either hands-off or micromanagers or managing in absentia, showing up on campus maybe once per month with rumors of other full time jobs in addition to high-paying MCCC jobs.

GROSS NEPOTISM/CRONYISM - Members of the MCCC college board of trustees have repeatedly had friends and relatives hired to full time, high paying internal positions, even when there are better candidates. These positions are all $100k-$200k+ jobs.

ADJUNCT MISTREATMENT - The administration has a belief that it doesn't matter if you mistreat adjunct faculty.  "Adjuncts are like Kleenex - use one up, get a new one" was even stated publicly at a full-time faculty meeting by one of the former Vice Presidents of Academic Affairs.

LACK OF ADVANCEMENT - Promises of full-time employment for adjunct teaching professionals are usually lies. The College has the current belief that attrition will drive full-time faculty down to 30 or so with an adjunct pool of hundreds. Don't believe the lies that a tenured faculty individual is going to be retiring soon and replaced. Most are not going to be replaced. But they will still dangle the prospect of full-time work to adjunct faculty.

All of this is done to help the bottom line of the college which is struggling with low enrollment. However, they keep adding more Vice Presidents almost monthly with high salaries. 

LOW ADJUNCT PAY / LACK OF RESPECT- Most adjunct faculty can only make a total of approximately $25k per year at MCCC even though the salary per hour is high. Although adjuncts make over $60/hour, they are precluded from working more than nine hours total. 

Administrative professionals start at $40k-$60k. Most of the staff positions start at $40k-$60k. They will gladly hire more full time staff, but not promote adjuncts to full time faculty.

The pay disparity and lack of respect from the VP level and above - where adjuncts are viewed with contempt - is well known.

POOR COMMUNICATION - Inter-departmental support from IT, maintenance, and facilities is relatively poor. They have no processes in place for industry-accepted infrastructure management. No one double checks if things are OK and working. Everything goes through the "schooldude" website, on a first-come, first-served basis - when they get to it. Yet things are still rarely completely correct once completed, with a lack of follow-through.

LACK OF COOPERATION - The board of trustees, the former College President, and VPs view the relationship with all faculty as antagonistic rather than cooperative. If the end goal is good learning outcomes and a positive environment, why make each conversation an argument? Shouldn't everyone have the same goals?

job_title: Security Officer (Full-time) in West Windsor, NJ
pros: you don't do much, good benefits.
cons: bad pay, boring... very boring.

job_title: Head Lifeguard in Hamilton, NJ
pros: I got my certification and my baseline requirements to move forward with my bachelor's degree here, as well as more experience in customer relations, my program of study, and progression towards my degree for less with tuition reimbursement. I've grown in experience and broadened my leadership skills with my time here
cons: With the COVID-19 related layoffs there has been a lapse in staff and judgements in a few cases I didn't agree with. I'm unsure of the direction this school is taking, but hope for the best to the people still there.

review_title: Minimal pay, but you're very independent
job_title: Adjunct Professor in West Windsor, NJ

cons: you get way you pay for - the adjunct staff is paid very little

job_title: Senior Associate Professor in Raleigh, NC
pros: Free credits for classes; retirement plan; life insurance
cons: Low pay, long hours, unpredictable assignments

job_title: Professor in West Windsor, NJ
pros: There are few pros about Mercer.  I genuinely can not think of anything that stands out.  The process to tenure is easy and is rarely challenged.
cons: Mercer staff rarely do their jobs, you can go for months without getting an email reply or a phone call if you have a question.  The Administration does not respect faculty or staff.  The pay is low, which wasn't so bad when our benefits were free, now we pay for our benefits too.  The facilities are horrendous, they manage their money poorly and are always scrambling to figure out how to cut something out to pay for something new.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in South Harrison Township, NJ
pros: Active departments interested in fostering academic growth. Larger than some of the other area 2 year colleges, which provides and opportunity to really add to the core curriculum.
cons: Students show high levels of burnout, a lot of effort is put into maintaining a class past the midterms.  Have heard new full time faculty complain they are put underneath long term adjuncts when it comes to choosing the classes they want to teach.

job_title: Security in West Windsor, NJ
pros: Very good commanding officer and second-in-command. They praise in public and discipline in private. Never loud or abusive in any situation.
cons: The college administration is decades behind in their integration of safety and security into management operations. Security of the campus, faculty, staff and students is an after thought.  Poor equipment, training and non-livable wage.

job_title: Head of Circulation Services in West Windsor, NJ
pros: Best health care coverage with minimum to almost no copay. vacation days, job security.
cons: Starting salary is pretty low compared to corporate jobs.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in West Windsor, NJ
pros: Nice working environment, the staff are supportive.
cons: pay is too low, the hourly pay does not take into account of class preparation, homework and tests grading time. In order to deliver quality teaching, those preparation and grading hours have to be taken into account. No benefit at all.

review_title: I last worked there in 2006, but that is not an option available.
